books.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:1
verses.text: On Marriage and Concupiscence Book II: preliminary notes on the second book.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:2
verses.text: (1) From the Preface of Augustin's "Unfinished Work Against Julianus".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:3
verses.text: I Wrote a treatise, under the title On Marriage and Concupiscence, and addressed it to the Count Valerius, on learning that he had been informed of the Pelagians that they charge us with condemning marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:4
verses.text: Now in that treatise I showed the distinction, as criticially and accurately as I was able, between the good of marriage and the evil of carnal concupiscence,—an evil which is well used by conjugal chastity.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:5
verses.text: On receiving my treatise, the illustrious man whom I have named sent me in a short paper a few sentences culled from a work of Julianus, a Pelagian heretic.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:6
verses.text: In this work he has thought fit to extend to four books his answer to the before-mentioned treatise of mine, which is limited to one book only, On Marriage and Concupiscence.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:7
verses.text: I do not know to whom we were indebted for the said extracts: he confined his selection, evidently on purpose, to the first book of Julianus' work.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:8
verses.text: At the request of Valerius, I lost no time in drawing up my answer to the extracts.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:9
verses.text: And thus it happened that I have written a second book also under the same title; and in reply to this Julianus has drawn up to eight books, in excess of his loquacious powers.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:10
verses.text: (2) From Augustin's Epistle to Claudius (CCVII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:11
Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:12
verses.text: "Whoever has perused this second book of mine, addressed (as the first was) to the Count Valerius, and drawn up (as, indeed, both were) for his use, will have discovered that there are some points in which I have not answered Julianus, but that I meant my work rather for him who made the extracts from that writer's books, and who did not arrange them in the order in which he found them.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:13
verses.text: He deemed some considerable alteration necessary in his arrangement, very probably with the view of appropriating by this method as his own the thoughts which evidently were another person's".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:14
verses.text: {{small-caps|Book II.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:15
verses.text: Augustin, in this latter book, refutes sundry sentences which had been culled by some unknown author from the first of four books that Julianus had published in opposition to the former book of his treatise "On Marriage and Concupiscence;" which sentences had been forwarded to him at the instance of the Count Valerius.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:16
verses.text: He vindicates the Catholic doctrine of original sin from his opponent's cavils and subtleties, and particularly shows how diverse it is from the infamous heresy of the Manicheans.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:17
verses.text: Chapter 1 (I.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:18
verses.text: )—Introductory Statement.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:19
verses.text: I Cannot tell you, dearly loved and honoured son Valerius, how great is the pleasure which my heart receives when I hear of your warm and earnest interest in the testimony of the word of God against the heretics; and this, too, amidst your military duties and the cares which devolve on you in the eminent position you so justly occupy, and the pressing functions, moreover, of your political life.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:20
verses.text: After reading the letter of your Eminence, in which you acknowledge the book which I dedicated to you, I was roused to write this also; for you request me to attend to the statement, which my brother and fellow-bishop Alypius is commissioned to make to me, about the discussion which is being raised by the heretics over sundry passages of my book.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:21
verses.text: Not only have I received this information from the narrative of my said brother, but I have also read the extracts which he produced, and which you had yourself forwarded to Rome, after his departure from Ravenna.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 1:22
verses.text: On discovering the boastful language of our adversaries, as I could easily do in these extracts, I determined, with the help of the Lord, to reply to their taunts with all the truthfulness and scriptural authority that I could command.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2 (II.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:2
verses.text: )—In This and the Four Next Chapters He Adduces the Garbled Extracts He Has to Consider.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:3
verses.text: The paper which I now answer starts with this title: "Headings out of a book written by Augustin, in reply to which I have culled a few passages out of books".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:4
verses.text: I perceive from this that the person who forwarded these written papers to your Excellency wanted to make his extracts out of the books he does not name, with a view, so far as I can judge, to getting a quicker answer, in order that he might not delay your urgency.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:5
verses.text: Now, after considering what books they were which he meant, I suppose that it must have been those which Julianus mentioned in the Epistle he sent to Rome, a copy of which found its way to me at the same time.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:6
verses.text: For he there says: "They go so far as to allege that marriage, now in dispute, was not instituted by God,—a declaration which may be read in a work of Augustin's, to which I have lately replied in a treatise of four books".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:7
verses.text: These are the books, as I believe, from which the extracts were taken.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:8
verses.text: It would, then, have been perhaps the better course if I had set myself deliberately to disprove and refute that entire work of his, which he spread out into four volumes.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 2:9
verses.text: But I was most unwilling to delay my answer, even as you yourself lost no time in forwarding to me the written statements which I was requested to reply to.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3:3
verses.text: The words which he has quoted and endeavoured to refute out of my book, which I sent to you, and with which you are very well acquainted, are the following: "They are constantly affirming, in their excessive hatred of us, that we condemn marriage and that divine procedure by which God creates human beings by means of men and women, inasmuch as we maintain that they who are born of such a union contract original sin, and do not deny that, of whatever parents they are born, they are still under the devil's dominion unless they be born again in Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3:4
verses.text: Now, in quoting these words of mine, he took care to omit the testimony of the apostle, which I adduced by the weighty significance of which he felt himself too hard pressed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3:5
verses.text: For, after saying that men at their birth contract original sin, I at once introduced the apostle's words: "By one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for in him all men sinned".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3:6
verses.text: Well, as I have already mentioned, he omitted this passage of the apostle, and then closed up the other remarks of mine which have been now quoted.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 3:7
verses.text: For he knew too well how acceptable to the hearts and consciences of all faithful catholics are these words of the apostle, which I had adopted, but which he omitted,—words which are so direct and so clear, that these new-fangled heretics use every effort in their dark and tortuous glosses to obscure and deprave their force.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:3
verses.text: But he has added other words of mine, where I have said: "Nor do they reflect that the good of marriage is no more impeachable by reason of the original evil which is derived therefrom, than the evil of adultery and fornication can be excused by reason of the natural good which is born of them.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:4
verses.text: For as sin is the work of the devil, whether derived from this source or from that; so is man, whether born of this or that, the work of God".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:5
verses.text: Here, too, he has left out some words, in which he was afraid of catholic ears.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:6
verses.text: For to come to the words here quoted, it had previously been said by us: "Because, then, we affirm this doctrine, which is contained in the oldest and unvarying rule of the catholic faith, these propounders of novel and perverse dogmas, who deny that there is in infants any sin to be washed away in the laver of regeneration, in their unbelief or ignorance calumniate us as if we condemned marriage, and as if we asserted to be the devil's work what is God's own work, to wit, the human being which is born of marriage".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:7
verses.text: All this passage he has passed over, and merely quoted the words which follow it, as given above.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:8
verses.text: Now, in the omitted words he was afraid of the clause which suits all hearts in the catholic Church and appeals to the very faith which has been firmly established and transmitted from ancient times with unfaltering voice and excites their hostility most strongly against us.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:9
verses.text: The clause is this: "They deny that there is in infants any sin to be washed away in the laver of regeneration".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 4:10
verses.text: For all persons run to church with their infants for no other reason in the world than that the original sin which is contracted in them by their first and natural birth may be cleansed by the regeneration of their second birth.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:3
verses.text: He then returns to our words, which were quoted before: "We maintain that they who are born of such a union contract original sin; and we do not deny that, of whatever parents they are born, they are still under the devil's dominion unless they be born again in Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:4
verses.text: Why he should again refer to these words of ours I cannot tell; he had already cited them a little before.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:5
verses.text: He then proceeds to quote what we said of Christ: "Who willed not to be born from the same union of the two sexes".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:6
verses.text: But here again he quietly ignored the words which I placed just previous to these words; my entire sentence being this: "That by His grace they may be removed from the power of darkness, and translated into the kingdom of Him who willed not to be born from the same union of the two sexes".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:7
verses.text: Observe, I pray you, what my words were which he shunned, in the temper of one who is thoroughly opposed to that grace of God which comes through our "Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:8
verses.text: He knows well enough that it is the height of improbity and impiety to exclude infants from their interest in the apostle's words, where he said of God the Father: "Who hath delivered us from the power of darkness, and hath translated us into the kingdom of His dear son".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 5:9
verses.text: This, no doubt, is the reason why he preferred to omit rather than quote these words.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:3
verses.text: He has next adduced that passage of ours, wherein we said: "For there would have been none of this shame-producing concupiscence, which is impudently praised by impudent men, if man had not previously sinned; while as to marriage, it would still have existed, even if no man had sinned: for the procreation of children would have been effected without this disease".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:4
verses.text: Up to this point he cited my words; but he shrank from adding what comes next—"in the body of that chaste life, although without it this cannot be done in 'the body of this death.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:5
verses.text: '" He would not complete my sentence, but mutilated it somewhat, because he dreaded the apostle's exclamation, of which my words gave him a reminder: "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death? The grace of God, through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:6
verses.text: For the body of this death existed not in paradise before sin; therefore did we say, "In the body of that chaste life," which was the life of paradise, "the procreation of children could have been effected without the disease, without which now in the body of this death it cannot be done".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:7
verses.text: The apostle, however, before arriving at that mention of man's misery and God's grace which we have just quoted, had first said: "I see another law in my members warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:8
verses.text: Then it is that he exclaimed, "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death? The grace of God, through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:9
verses.text: In the body of this death, therefore, such as it was in paradise before sin, there certainly was not "another law in our members warring against the law of our mind"—which now, even when we are unwilling, and withhold consent, and use not our members to fulfil that which it desires, still dwells in these members, and harasses our resisting and repugnant mind.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:10
verses.text: And this conflict in itself, although not involving condemnation, because it does not consummate sin, is nevertheless "wretched," inasmuch as it has no peace.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 6:11
verses.text: I think, then, that I have shown you clearly enough that this man had a special object as well as method in quoting my words: he adduced them for refutation in such manner as in some instances to interrupt the context of my sentences by removing what stood between them, and in other instances to curtail them by withdrawing their concluding words; and his reason for doing all this I think I have sufficiently explained.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7 (III.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:2
verses.text: )—Augustin Adduces a Passage Selected from the Preface of Julianus.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:3
verses.text: (See "The Unfinished Work," i.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:4
Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:5
verses.text: )  Let us now look at those words of ours which he adduced just as it suited him, and to which he would oppose his own.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:6
verses.text: For they are followed by his words; moreover, as the person insinuated who sent you the paper of extracts, he copied something out of a preface, which was no doubt the preface of the books from which he selected a few passages.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:7
verses.text: The paragraph thus copied stands as follows: "The teachers of our day, most holy brother, who are the instigators of the disgraceful faction which is now overheated with its zeal, are determined on compassing the injury and discredit of the men with whose sacred fervour they are set on fire, by nothing less than the ruin of the whole Church; little thinking how much honour they have conferred on those whose renown they have shown to be only capable of being destroyed along with the catholic religion.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:8
verses.text: For, if one should say, either that there is free will in man, or that God is the Creator of those that are born, he is at once set down as a Coelestian and a Pelagian.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 7:9
verses.text: To avoid being called heretics, they turn Manicheans; and so, whilst shirking a pretended infamy, they incur a real reproach; just like the animals, which in hunting they surround with dyed feathers, in order to scare and drive them into their nets; the poor brutes are not gifted with reason, and so they are thrust all together by a vain panic into a real destruction".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:2
verses.text: —Augustin Refutes the Passage Adduced Above.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:3
verses.text: Well, now, whoever you are that have said all this, what you say is by no means true; by no means, I repeat; you are much deceived, or you aim at deceiving others.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:4
verses.text: We do not deny free will; but, even as the Truth declares, "if the Son shall make you free, then shall ye be free indeed".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:5
verses.text: It is yourselves who invidiously deny this Liberator, since you ascribe a vain liberty to yourselves in your captivity.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:6
verses.text: Captives you are; for "of whom a man is overcome," as the Scripture says, "of the same is he brought in bondage;" and no one except by the grace of the great Liberator is loosed from the chain of this bondage, from which no man living is free.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:7
verses.text: For "by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for in him all have sinned".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:8
verses.text: Thus, then, God is the Creator of those that are born in such wise that all pass from the one into condemnation, who have not the One Liberator by regeneration.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:9
verses.text: For He is described as "the Potter, forming out of the same lump one vessel unto honour in His mercy, and another unto dishonour in judgment".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:10
verses.text: And so runs the Church's canticle "mercy and judgment".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:11
verses.text: You are therefore only misleading yourself and others when you say, "If one should affirm, either that there is free will in man, or that God is the Creator of those that are born, he is at once set down as a Coelestian and a Pelagian;" for the catholic faith says these things.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:12
verses.text: If, however, any one says that there is a free will in man for worshipping God aright, without His assistance; and whosoever says that God is the Creator of those that are born in such wise as to deny that infants have any need of one to redeem them from the power of the devil: that is the man who is set down as a disciple of Coelestius and Pelagius.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:13
verses.text: Therefore that men have within them a free will, and that God is the Creator of those that are born, are propositions which we both allow.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:14
verses.text: You are not Coelestians and Pelagians for merely saying this.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:15
verses.text: But what you do really say is this, that any man whatever has freedom enough of will for doing good without God's help, and that infants undergo no such change as being "delivered from the power of darkness and translated into the kingdom of God;" and because you say so, you are Coelestians and Pelagians.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 8:16
verses.text: Why, then, do you hide under the covering of a common dogma for deceit, concealing your own especial delinquency which has gained for you a party-name; and why, to terrify the ignorant with a shocking term, do you say of us, "To avoid being called heretics, they turn Manicheans?".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:2
verses.text: —The Catholics Maintain the Doctrine of Original Sin, and Thus are Far from Being Manicheans.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:3
verses.text: Listen, then, for a little while, and observe what is involved in this question.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:4
verses.text: Catholics say that human nature was created good by the good God as Creator; but that, having been corrupted by sin, it needs the physician Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:5
verses.text: The Manicheans affirm, that human nature was not created by God good, and corrupted by sin; but that man was formed by the prince of eternal darkness of a mixture of two natures which had ever existed—one good and the other evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:6
verses.text: The Pelagians and Coelestians say that human nature was created good by the good God; but that it is still so sound and healthy in infants at their birth, that they have no need at that age of Christ's medicine.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:7
verses.text: Recognise, then, your name in your dogma; and cease from intruding upon the catholics, who refute you, a name and a dogma which belong to others.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:8
verses.text: For truth rejects both parties—the Manicheans and yourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:9
verses.text: To the Manicheans it says: "Have ye not read that He which made man at the beginning, made them male and female; and said, For this cause shall a man leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife; and they twain shall be one flesh? Wherefore they are no more twain, but one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:10
verses.text: What, therefore, God hath joined together, let not man put asunder".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:11
verses.text: Now Christ shows, in this passage, that God is both the Creator of man, and the uniter in marriage of husband and wife; whereas the Manicheans deny both these propositions.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:12
verses.text: To you, however, He says: "The Son of man is come to seek and to save that which is lost".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:13
verses.text: But you, admirable Christians as you are, answer Christ: "If you came to seek and to save that which was lost, then you did not come for infants; for they were not lost, but are born in a state of salvation: go to older men; we give you a rule from your own words: 'They that be whole need not a physician, but they that are sick.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:14
verses.text: '" Now, as it happens, the Manichean, who says that man has evil mixed in his nature, must wish his good soul at any rate to be saved by Christ; whereas you contend that there is in infants nothing to be sired by Christ, since they are already safe.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:15
verses.text: And thus the Manichean besets human nature with his detestable censure, and you with your cruel praise.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:16
verses.text: For whosoever shall believe your laudation, will never bring their babes to the Saviour.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:17
verses.text: Entertaining such impious views as these, of what use is it that you fearlessly face that which is enacted for you in order to induce salutary fear and to treat you as a human being, and not as that poor animal of yours which was surrounded with the coloured feathers to be driven into the hunting toils? Need was that you should hold the truth, and, on account of zeal for it, have no fear; but, as things are, you evade fear in such wise that, if you feared, you would rather run away from the net of the malignant one than run into it.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:18
verses.text: The reason why your catholic mother alarms you is, because she fears for both you and others from you; and if by the help of her sons who possess any authority in the State she acts with a view to make you afraid, she does so, not from cruelty, but from love.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:19
verses.text: You, however, are a very brave man; and you deem it the coward's part to be afraid of men.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:20
verses.text: Well then, fear God; and do not try with such obstinacy to subvert the ancient foundations of the catholic faith.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:21
verses.text: Although I could even wish that spirited temper of yours would entertain some little fear of human authority, at least in the present case.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 9:22
verses.text: I could wish, I say, that it would rather tremble through cowardice than perish through audacity.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 10

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10 (IV.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 10:2
verses.text: )—In What Manner the Adversary's Cavils Must Be Refuted.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 10:3
verses.text: Let us now look at the rest of what he has joined together in his selections.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 10:4
verses.text: But what should be my course of proceeding? Ought I to set forth every passage of his for the purpose of answering it, or, omitting everything which the catholic faith contains, as not in dispute between us, only handle and confute those statements in which he strays away from the beaten path of truth, and endeavours to graft on catholic stems the poisonous shoots of his Pelagian heresy? This is, no doubt, the easier course.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 10:5
verses.text: But I suppose I must not lose sight of a possible contingency, that any one, after reading my book, without perusing all that has been alleged by him, may think that I was unwilling to bring forward the passages on which his allegations depend, and by which are shown to be truly deduced the statements which I am controverting as false.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 10:6
verses.text: I should be glad, therefore, if the reader will without exception kindly observe and consider the two classes of contributions which occur in this little work of ours—that is to say, all that he has alleged, and the answers which on my side I give him.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11:2
verses.text: —The Devil the Author, Not of Nature, But Only of Sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11:3
verses.text: Now, the man who forwarded to your Love the paper in question has introduced the contents thereof with this title: "In opposition to those persons who condemn matrimony, and ascribe its fruits to the devil".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11:4
verses.text: This, then, is not in opposition to us, who neither condemn matrimony, which we even commend in its order with a just commendation, nor ascribe its fruits to the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11:5
verses.text: For the fruits of matrimony are men which are orderly engendered from it, and not the sins which accompany their birth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11:6
verses.text: Human beings are not under the devil's dominion because they are human beings, in which respect they are the fruits of matrimony; but because they are sinful, in which resides the transmission of their sins.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 11:7
verses.text: For the devil is the author of sin, not of nature.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:2
verses.text: —Eve's Name Means Life, and is a Great Sacrament of the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:3
verses.text: Now, observe the rest of the passage in which he thinks he finds, to our prejudice, what is consonant with the above-quoted title.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:4
verses.text: "God," says he, "who had framed Adam out of the dust of the ground, formed Eve out of his rib, and said, She shall be called Life, because she is the mother of all who live".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:5
verses.text: Well now, it is not so written.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:6
verses.text: But what matters that to us? For it constantly happens that our memory fails in verbal accuracy, while the sense is still maintained.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:7
verses.text: Nor was it God, but her husband, who gave Eve her name, which should signify Life; for thus it is written: "And Adam called his wife's name Life, because she is the mother of all living".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:8
verses.text: But very likely he might have understood the Scripture as testifying that God gave Eve this name through Adam, as His prophet.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:9
verses.text: For in that she was called Life, and the mother of all living, there lies a great sacrament of the Church, of which it would detain us long to speak, and which is unnecessary to our present undertaking.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:10
verses.text: The very same thing which the apostle says, "This is a great sacrament: but I speak concerning Christ and the Church," was also spoken by Adam when he said, "For this cause shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife; and they twain shall be one flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:11
verses.text: The Lord Jesus, however, in the Gospel mentions God as having said this of Eve; and the reason, no doubt, is, that God declared through the man what the man, in fact, uttered as a prophecy.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:12
verses.text: Now, observe what follows in the paper of extracts: "By that primitive name," says he, "He showed for what labour the woman had been provided; and He said accordingly, 'Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:13
verses.text: '" Now, who amongst ourselves denies that the woman was provided for the work of child-bearing by the Lord God, the beneficent Creator of all good? See further what he goes on to say: "God, therefore, who created them male and female, furnished them with members suitable for procreation, and ordained that bodies should be produced from bodies; and yet is security for their capacity for effecting the work, executing all that exists with that power which He used in creation".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 12:14
verses.text: Well, even this we acknowledge to be catholic doctrine, as we also do with regard to the passage which he immediately subjoins: "If, then, offspring comes only through sex, and sex only through the body, and the body through God, who can hesitate to allow that fecundity is rightly attributed to God?".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:2
verses.text: —The Pelagian Argument to Show that the Devil Has No Rights in the Fruits of Marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:3
verses.text: After these true and catholic statements, which are, moreover, really contained in the Holy Scriptures, although they are not adduced by him in a catholic spirit, with the earnestness of a catholic mind, he loses no time in introducing to us the heresy of Pelagius and Coelestius, for which purpose he wrote, indeed, his previous remarks.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:4
verses.text: Mark carefully the following words: "You now who say, 'We do not deny that they, are still, of whatever parents born, under the devil's power, unless they be born again in Christ,' show us what the devil can recognise as his own in the sexes, by reason of which he can (to use your phrase) rightly claim as his property the fruit which they produce.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:5
verses.text: Is it the difference of the sexes? But this is inherent in the bodies which God made.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:6
verses.text: Is it their union? But this union is justified in the privilege of the primeval blessing no less than institution.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:7
verses.text: For it is the voice of God that says, 'A man shall leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave to his wife; and they two shall be one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:8
verses.text: ' It is again the voice of God which says, 'Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 13:9
verses.text: ' Or is it, perchance, their fertility? But this is the very reason why matrimony was instituted".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14 (V.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:2
verses.text: )—Concupiscence Alone, in Marriage, is Not of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:3
verses.text: You see the terms of his question to us: what the devil can find in the sexes to call his own, by reason of which they should be in his power, who are born of parents of whatsoever kind, unless they be born again in Christ; he asks us, moreover, whether it is the difference in the sexes which we ascribe to the devil, or their union, or their very fruitfulness.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:4
verses.text: We answer, then, nothing of these qualities, inasmuch as the difference of sex belongs to "the vessels" of the parents; while the union of the two pertains to the procreation of children; and their fruitfulness to the blessing pronounced on the marriage institution.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:5
verses.text: But all these things are of God; yet amongst them he was unwilling to name that "lust of the flesh, which is not of the Father, but is of the world;" and "of this world" the devil is said to be "the prince".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:6
verses.text: Now, the devil found no carnal concupiscence in the Lord, because the Lord did not come as a man to men by its means.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:7
verses.text: Accordingly, He says Himself: "The prince of this world cometh, and findeth nothing in me"—nothing, that is, of sin; neither that which is derived from birth, nor that which is added during life.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:8
verses.text: Among all the natural goods of procreation which he mentioned, he was, I repeat, unwilling to name this particular fact of concupiscence, over which even marriage blushes, which glories in all these before-mentioned goods.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:9
verses.text: For why is the especial work of parents withdrawn and hidden even from the eyes of their children, except that it is impossible for them to be occupied in laudable procreation without shameful lust? Because of this it was that even they were ashamed who first covered their nakedness.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:10
verses.text: These portions of their person were not suggestive of shame before, but deserved to be commended and praised as the work of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:11
verses.text: They put on their covering when they felt their shame, and they felt their shame when, after their own disobedience to their Maker, they felt their members disobedient to themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:12
verses.text: Our quoter of extracts likewise felt ashamed of this concupiscence.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:13
verses.text: For he mentioned the difference of the sexes; he mentioned also their union, and he mentioned their fertility; but this last concomitant of lust he blushed to mention.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 14:14
verses.text: And no wonder if mere talkers are ashamed of that which we see parents themselves, so interested in their function, blush to think of.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:2
verses.text: —Man, by Birth, is Placed Under the Dominion of the Devil Through Sin; We Were All One in Adam When He Sinned.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:3
verses.text: He then proceeds to ask: "Why, then, are they in the devil's power whom God created?" And he finds an answer to his own question apparently from a phrase of mine.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:4
verses.text: "Because of sin," says he, "not because of nature".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:5
verses.text: Then framing his answer in reference to mine, he says: "But as there cannot be offspring without the sexes, so there cannot be sin without the will".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:6
verses.text: Yes, indeed, such is the truth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:7
verses.text: For even as "by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; so also has death passed through to all men, for in him all have sinned".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:8
verses.text: By the evil will of that one man all sinned in him, since all were that one man, from whom, therefore, they individually derived original sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:9
verses.text: "For you allege," says he, "that the reason why they are in the devil's power is because they are born of the union of the two sexes".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:10
verses.text: I plainly aver that it is by reason of transgression that they are in the devil's power, and that their participation, moreover, of this transgression is due to the circumstance that they are born of the said union of the sexes, which cannot even accomplish its own honourable function without the incident of shameful lust.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:11
verses.text: This has also, in fact, been said by Ambrose, of most blessed memory, bishop of the church in Milan, when he gives as the reason why Christ's birth in the flesh was free from all sinful fault, that His conception was not the result of a union of the two sexes; whereas there is not one among human beings conceived in such union who is without sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:12
verses.text: These are his precise words: "On that account, and being man, He was tried by every sort of temptation, and in the likeness of man He bore them all; inasmuch, however, as He was born of the Spirit, He abstained from all sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:13
verses.text: For every man is a liar, and none is without sin, but God only.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:14
verses.text: It has accordingly," adds he, "been constantly observed, that clearly no one who is born of a man and a woman, that is to say, through the union of their bodies, is free from sin; for whoever is free from sin is free also from conception of this kind".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:15
verses.text: Well now, will you dare, ye disciples of Pelagius and Coelestius, to call this man a Manichean? as the heretic Jovinian did, when the holy bishop maintained the permanent virginity of the blessed Mary even after child-bearing, in opposition to this man's impiety.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:16
verses.text: If, however, you do not dare to call him a Manichean, why do you call us Manicheans when we defend the catholic faith in the self-same cause and with the self same opinions? But if you will taunt that most faithful man with having entertained Manichean error in this matter, there is no help for it, you must enjoy your taunts as best you may, and so fill up Jovinian's measure more fully; as for ourselves, we can patiently endure along with such a man of God your taunts and jibes.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:17
verses.text: And yet your heresiarch Pelagius commends Ambrose's faith and extreme purity in the knowledge of the Scriptures so greatly, as to declare that not even an enemy could venture to find fault with him.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:18
verses.text: Observe, then, to what length you have gone, and refrain from following any further in the audacious steps of Jovinian.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:19
verses.text: And yet that man, although by his excessive commendation of marriage he put it on a par with holy virginity, never denied the necessity of Christ to save those who are born of marriage even fresh from their mother's womb, and to redeem them from the power of the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:20
verses.text: This, however, you deny; and because we oppose you in defence of those who cannot yet speak for themselves, and in defence of the very foundations of the catholic faith, you taunt us, with being Manicheans.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 15:21
verses.text: But let us now see what comes next.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16 (VI.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:2
verses.text: )—It is Not of Us, But Our Sins, that the Devil is the Author.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:3
verses.text: He puts to us, then, another question, saying, "Whom, then, do you confess to be the author of infants? The true God?" I answer: "Yes; the true God".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:4
verses.text: He then remarks, "But He did not make evil;" and again asks, "Whether we confess the devil to be the creator of infants?" Then again he answers, "But he did not create human nature".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:5
verses.text: He then closes the subject, as it were, with this inference: "Since union is evil, and the condition of our bodies is degraded, therefore you ascribe our bodies to an evil creator".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:6
verses.text: My answer to this is, I do not ascribe to an evil creator our bodies, but our sins; by reason of which it came to pass that, whereas in our bodies, that is to say, in what God has made, all was honourable and well-pleasing, there yet accrued in the intercourse of male and female what caused shame, so that their union was not such as might have been in the body of that unimpaired life, but such as we see with a blush in the body of this death.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:7
verses.text: "But God," says he, "has divided in sex what He would unite in operation.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:8
verses.text: So that from Him comes the union of bodies, from whom first came the creation of bodies".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:9
verses.text: We have already furnished an answer to this statement, when we said that these bodies are of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:10
verses.text: But as regards the disobedience of the members of these bodies, this comes through the lust of the flesh which "is not of the Father".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:11
verses.text: He goes on to say, that "it is impossible for evil fruits to spring from so many good things, such as bodies, sexes, and their unions; or that human beings should be made by God for the purpose of their being, by lawful right, as you maintain, held in possession by the devil".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 16:12
verses.text: Now it has been already affirmed, that they are not thus held because they are men, which designation belongs to their nature, of which the devil is not the author; but because they are sinners, which designation is the result of that fault of nature of which the devil is the author.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17 (VII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:2
verses.text: )—The Pelagians are Not Ashamed to Eulogize Concupiscence, Although They are Ashamed to Mention Its Name.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:3
verses.text: But among so many names of good things, such as bodies, sexes, unions, he never once mentions the lust or concupiscence of the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:4
verses.text: He is silent, because he is ashamed; and yet with a strange shamelessness of shame (if the expression may be used), he is not ashamed to praise what he is ashamed to mention.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:5
verses.text: Now just observe how he prefers to point to his object by circumlocution rather than by direct mention of it.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:6
verses.text: "After that the man," says he, "by natural appetite knew his wife".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:7
verses.text: See again, he refused to say, He knew his wife by carnal concupiscence; but he used the phrase, "by natural appetite," by which it is open to us to understand that holy and honourable will which wills the procreation of children, and not that lust, of which even he is so much ashamed, forsooth, that he prefers to use ambiguous language to us, to expressing his mind in unmistakeable words.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:8
verses.text: "Now what is the meaning of his phrase—"by natural appetite"? Is not both the wish to be saved and the wish to beget, nourish, and educate children, natural appetite? and is it not likewise of reason, and not of lust? Since, however, we can ascertain his intention, we are pretty sure that he meant by these words to indicate the lust of the organs of generation.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:9
verses.text: Do not the words in question appear to you to be the fig-leaves, under cover of which is hidden nothing else but that which he feels ashamed of? For just as they of old sewed the leaves together  as a girdle of concealment, so has this man woven a web of circumlocution to hide his meaning.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:10
verses.text: Let him weave out his statement: "But when the man knew his wife by natural appetite, the divine Scripture says, Eve conceived, and bare a son, and called his name Cain.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:11
verses.text: But what," he adds, "does Adam say? Let us hear: I have obtained a man from God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:12
verses.text: So that it is evident that he was God's work, and the divine Scripture testifies to his having been received from God".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 17:13
verses.text: Well, who can entertain a doubt on this point? Who can deny this statement, especially if he be a catholic Christian? A man is God's work; but carnal concupiscence (without which, if sin had not preceded, man would have been begotten by means of the organs of generation, not less obedient than the other members to a quiet and normal will) is not of the Father, but is of the world.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:3
verses.text: But now, I pray you, look a little more attentively, and observe how he contrives to find a name wherewith to cover again what he blushes to unfold.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:4
verses.text: "For," says he, "Adam begot him by the power of his members, not by diversity of merits".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:5
verses.text: Now I confess I do not understand what he meant by the latter clause, not by diversity of merits; but when he said, "by the power of his members," I believe he wished to express what he is ashamed to say openly and clearly.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:6
verses.text: He preferred to use the phrase, "by the power of his members," rather than say, "by the lust of the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:7
verses.text: Plainly—even if the thought did not occur to him—he intimated a something which has an evident application to the subject.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:8
verses.text: For what is more powerful than a man's members, when they are not in due submission to a man's will? Even if they be restrained by temperance or continence, their use and control are not in any man's power.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:9
verses.text: Adam, then, begat his sons by what our author calls "the power of his members," over which, before he begat them, he blushed, after his sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:10
verses.text: If, however, he had never sinned, he would not have begotten them by the power, but in the obedience, of his members.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 18:11
verses.text: For he would himself have had the power to rule them as subjects to his will, if he, too, by the same will had only submitted himself as a subject to a more powerful One.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 19 (VIII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:2
verses.text: )—The Pelagians Misunderstand "Seed" In Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:3
verses.text: He goes on to say: "After a while the divine Scripture says again, 'Adam knew Eve his wife; and she bare a son, and he called his name Seth: saying, The Lord hath raised me up another seed instead of Abel, whom Cain slew.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:4
verses.text: '" He then adds: "The Divinity is said to have raised up the seed itself; as a proof that the sexual union was His appointment".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:5
verses.text: This person did not understand what the Scripture records; for he supposed that the reason why it is said, The Lord hath raised me up another seed instead of Abel, was none other than that God might be supposed to have excited in him a desire for sexual intercourse, by means whereof seed might be raised for being poured into the woman's womb.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:6
verses.text: He was perfectly unaware that what the Scripture has said is not "Has raised me up seed" in the sense he uses, but only as meaning "Has given me a son".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:7
verses.text: Indeed, Adam did not use the words in question after his sexual intercourse, when he emitted his seed, but after his wife's confinement, in which he received his son by the gift of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 19:8
verses.text: For what gratification is there (except perhaps for lascivious persons, and those who, as the apostle says with prohibition, "possess their vessel in the lust of concupiscence") in the mere shedding of seed as the ultimate pleasure of sexual union, unless it is followed by the true and proper fruit of marriage—conception and birth?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 20.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:2
verses.text: —Original Sin is Derived from the Faulty Condition of Human Seed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:3
verses.text: This, however, I would not say, as implying at all that we must look for some other creator than the supreme and true God, of either human seed or of man himself who comes from the seed; but as meaning, that the seed would have issued from the human being by the quiet and normal obedience of his members to his will's command, if sin had not preceded.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:4
verses.text: The question now before us does not concern the nature of human seed, but its corruption.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:5
verses.text: Now the nature has God for its author; it is from its corruption that original sin is derived.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:6
verses.text: If, indeed, the seed had itself no corruption, what means that passage in the Book of Wisdom, "Not being ignorant that they were a naughty generation, and that their malice was inbred, and that their cogitation would never be changed; for their seed was accursed from the beginning"? Now whatever may be the particular application of these words, they are spoken of mankind.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:7
verses.text: How, then, is the malice of every man inbred, and his seed cursed from the beginning, unless it be in respect of the fact, that "by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for in him all have sinned"? But where is the man whose "evil cogitation can never be changed," unless because it cannot be effected by himself, but only by divine grace; without the assistance of which, what are human beings, but that which the Apostle Peter says of them, when he describes them as "natural brute beasts made to be taken and destroyed"? Accordingly, the Apostle Paul, in a certain passage, having both conditions in view,—even the wrath of God with which we are born, and the grace whereby we are delivered,—says: "Among whom also we all had our conversation in times past in the lusts of our flesh, fulfilling the desires of the flesh and of the mind; and were by nature the children of wrath, even as others.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:8
verses.text: But God, who is rich in mercy, for His great love wherewith He loved us, even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ; by whose grace we are saved".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 20:9
verses.text: What, then, is man's "natural malice," and "the seed cursed from the beginning;" and what are "the natural brute beasts made to be taken and destroyed," and what the "by nature children of wrath"? Was this the condition of the nature which was formed in Adam? God forbid! Inasmuch as his pure nature, however, was corrupted in him, it has run on in this condition by natural descent through all, and still is running; so that there is no deliverance for it from this ruin, except by the grace of God through our Lord Jesus Christ.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 21 (IX.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:2
verses.text: )—It is the Good God That Gives Fruitfulness, and the Devil That Corrupts the Fruit.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:3
verses.text: What, therefore, is this man's meaning, in the next passage, wherein he says concerning Noah and his sons, that "they were blessed, even as Adam and Eve were; for God said unto them, 'Be fruitful, and multiply, and have dominion over the earth'"? To these words of the Almighty he added some of his own, saying: "Now that pleasure, which you would have seem diabolical, was resorted to in the case of the above-mentioned married pairs; and it continued to exist, both in the goodness of its institution and in the blessing attached to it.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:4
verses.text: For there can be no doubt that the following words were addressed to Noah and his sons in reference to their bodily connection with their wives, which had become by this time unalterably fixed by use: 'Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:5
verses.text: '" It is unnecessary for us to employ many words in repeating our former argument.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:6
verses.text: The point here in question is the corruption in our nature, whereby its goodness has been depraved, of which corruption the devil is the author.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:7
verses.text: That goodness of nature, as it is in itself, the author of which is God, is not the question we have to consider.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:8
verses.text: Now God has never withdrawn from corrupted and depraved nature His own mercy and goodness, so as to deprive man of fruitfulness, vivacity, and health, as well as the very substance of his mind and body, his senses also and reason, as well as food, and nourishment, and growth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 21:9
verses.text: He, moreover, "maketh His sun to arise on the evil and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust;" and all that is good in human nature is from the good God, even in the case of those men who will not be delivered from evil.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 22.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:2
verses.text: —Shall We Be Ashamed of What We Do, or of What God Does?  It is, however, of pleasure that this man spoke in his passage, because pleasure can be even honourable: of carnal concupiscence, or lust, which produces shame, he made no mention.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:3
verses.text: In some subsequent words, however, he uncovered his susceptibility of shame; and he was unable to dissemble what nature herself has prescribed so forcibly.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:4
verses.text: "There is also," says he, "that statement: 'Therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife; and they twain shall be one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:5
verses.text: '" Then after these words of God, he goes on to offer some of his own, saying: "That he might express faith in works, the prophet approached very near to a perilling of modesty".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:6
verses.text: What a confession! How clear and extorted from him by the force of truth! The prophet, it would seem, to express faith in works, almost imperilled modesty, when he said, "They twain shall become one flesh;" wishing it to be understood of the sexual union of the male and the female.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:7
verses.text: Let the cause be alleged, why the prophet, in expressing the works of God, should approach so near an imperilling of modesty? Is it then the case that the works of man ought not to produce shame, but must be gloried in at all events, and that the works of God must produce shame? Is it, that in setting forth and expressing the works of God the prophet's love or labour receives no honour, but his modesty is imperilled? What, then, was it possible for God to do, which it would be a shame for His prophet to describe? And, what is a weightier question still, could a man be ashamed of any work which not man, but God, has made in man? whereas workmen in all cases strive, with all the labour and diligence in their power, to avoid shame in the works of their own hands.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:8
verses.text: The truth, however, is, that we are ashamed of that very thing which made those primitive human beings ashamed, when they covered their loins.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:9
verses.text: That is the penalty of sin; that is the plague and mark of sin; that is the temptation and very fuel of sin; that is the law in our members warring against the law of our mind; that is the rebellion against our own selves, proceeding from our very selves, which by a most righteous retribution is rendered us by our disobedient members.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:10
verses.text: It is this which makes us ashamed, and justly ashamed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 22:11
verses.text: If it were not so, what could be more ungrateful, more irreligious in us, if in our members we were to suffer confusion of face, not for our own fault or penalty, but because of the works of God?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 23 (X.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:2
verses.text: )—The Pelagians Affirm that God in the Case of Abraham and Sarah Aroused Concupiscence as a Gift from Heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:3
verses.text: He has much also to say, though to no purpose, concerning Abraham and Sarah, how they received a son according to the promise; and at last he mentions the word concupiscence.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:4
verses.text: But he does not add the usual phrase, "of the flesh," because this is the very thing which causes the shame.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:5
verses.text: Whereas, on account of concupiscence there is sometimes a call for boasting, inasmuch as there is a concupiscence of the spirit against the flesh,  and a concupiscence of wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:6
verses.text: Accordingly, he says: "Now you have certainly defined as naturally evil this concupiscence which is indispensable for fecundity; whence comes it, therefore, that it is aroused in aged men by the gift of Heaven? Make it clear then, if you can, that that belongs to the devil's work, which you see is conferred by God as a gift".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:7
verses.text: He says this, just as if concupiscence of the flesh had been previously wanting in them, and as if God had bestowed it upon them.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:8
verses.text: No doubt it was inherent in this body of death; that fecundity, however, was wanting of which God is the author; and this was actually given whensoever God willed to confer the gift.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 23:9
verses.text: Be it, however, far from us to affirm, what he thought we meant to say, that Isaac was begotten without the heat of sexual union.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:1
verses.text: Chapter 24 (XI.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:2
verses.text: )—What Covenant of God the New-Born Babe Breaks.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:3
verses.text: What Was the Value of Circumcision.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:4
verses.text: But let him inform us how it was that his soul would be cut off from his people if he had not been circumcised on the eighth day.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:5
verses.text: How could he have so sinned, how so offended God, as to be punished for the neglect of others towards him with so severe a sentence, had there been no original sin in the case? For thus ran the commandment of God concerning the circumcision of infants: "The uncircumcised man-child, whose flesh of his foreskin is not circumcised on the eighth day, his soul shall be cut off from his people; because he hath broken my covenant".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:6
verses.text: Let him tell us, if he can, how that child broke God's covenant,—an innocent babe, so far as he was personally concerned, of eight days' age; and yet there is by no means any falsehood uttered here by God or Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:7
verses.text: The fact is, the covenant of God which he then broke was not this which commanded circumcision, but that which forbade the tree; when "by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for in him all have sinned".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:8
verses.text: And in his case the expiation of this was signified by the circumcision of the eighth day, that is, by the sacrament of the Mediator who was to be incarnate.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:9
verses.text: For it was through this same faith in Christ, who was to come in the flesh, and was to die for us, and on the third day (which coming after the seventh or Sabbath day, was to be the eighth) to rise again, that even holy men were saved of old.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:10
verses.text: For "He was delivered for our offences, and raised again for our justification".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:11
verses.text: Ever since circumcision was instituted amongst the people of God, which was at that time the sign of the righteousness of faith, it availed also to signify the cleansing even in infants of the original and primitive sin, just as baptism in like manner from the time of its institution began to be of avail for the renewal of man.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:12
verses.text: Not that there was no justification by faith before circumcision; for even when he was still in uncircumcision, Abraham was himself justified by faith, being the father of those nations which should also imitate his faith.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:13
verses.text: In former times, however, the sacramental mystery of justification by faith lay concealed in every mode.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:14
verses.text: Still it was the self-same faith in the Mediator which saved the saints of old, both small and great—not the old covenant, "which gendereth to bondage;" not the law, which was not so given as to be able to give life; but the grace of God through Jesus Christ our Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:15
verses.text: For as we believe that Christ has come in the flesh, so they believed that He was to come; as, again, we believe that He has died, so they believed that He would die; and as we believe that He has risen from the dead, so they believed that He would rise again; whilst both we and they believe alike, that He will hereafter come to judge the quick and the dead.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 24:16
verses.text: Let not this man, then, throw any hindrance in the way of its salvation upon human nature, by setting up a bad defence of its merits; because we are all born under sin, and are delivered therefrom by the only One who was born without sin.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:1
verses.text: Chapter 25 (XII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:2
verses.text: )—Augustin Not the Deviser of Original Sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:3
verses.text: "This sexual connection of bodies," he says, "together with the ardour, with the pleasure, with the emission of seed, was made by God, and is praiseworthy on its own account, and is therefore to be approved; it, moreover, became sometimes even a great gift to pious men".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:4
verses.text: He distinctly and severally repeated the phrases, "with ardour," "with pleasure," "with emission of seed".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:5
verses.text: He did not, however, venture to say, "with lust".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:6
verses.text: Why is this, if it be not that he is ashamed to name what he does not blush to praise? A gift, indeed, for pious men is the prosperous propagation of children; but not that shame-producing excitement of the members, which our nature would not feel were it in a sound state, although corrupted nature now experiences it.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:7
verses.text: On this account, indeed, it is that he who is born of it requires to be born again, in order that he may be a member of Christ; and that he of whom he is born, even though he be already born again, wants to be freed from that which exists in this body of death by reason of the law of sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:8
verses.text: Now since this is the case, how is it he goes on to say, "You must, therefore, of necessity confess that the original sin which you had devised is done away with"? It was not I who devised the original sin, which the catholic faith holds from ancient times; but you, who deny it, are undoubtedly an innovating heretic.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 25:9
verses.text: In the judgment of God, all are in the devil's power, born in sin, unless they are regenerated in Christ.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 26 (XIII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:2
verses.text: )—The Child in No Sense Formed by Concupiscence.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:3
verses.text: But as he was speaking of Abraham and Sarah, he goes on to say: "If, indeed, you were to affirm that the natural use was strong in them, and there was no offspring, my answer will be: Whom the Creator promised, the Creator also gave; the child which is born is not the work of cohabitation, but of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:4
verses.text: He, indeed, who made the first man of the dust, fashions all men out of seed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:5
verses.text: As, therefore, the dust of the earth, which was taken as the material, was not the author of man; so likewise that power of sexual pleasure which forms and commingles the seminal elements does not complete the entire process of man's making, but rather presents to God, out of the treasures of nature, material with which He vouchsafes to make the human being".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:6
verses.text: Now the whole of this statement of his, except where he says, that the seminal elements are formed and commingled by sexual pleasure, would be correctly expressed by him were he only earnest in making it to defend the catholic sense.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:7
verses.text: To us, however, who are fully aware what he strives to make out of it, he speaks indeed correctly in a perverse manner.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:8
verses.text: The exceptional statement to the general truth, which I do not deny belongs to this passage, is untrue for this reason, because the pleasure in question of carnal concupiscence does not form the seminal elements.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:9
verses.text: These are already in the body, and are formed by the same true God who created the body itself.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:10
verses.text: They do not receive their existence from the libidinous pleasure, but are excited and emitted in company with it.
