verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:11
verses.text: Whether, indeed, such pleasure accompanies the commingling of the seminal elements of the two sexes in the womb, is a question which perhaps women may be able to determine from their inmost feelings; but it is improper for us to push an idle curiosity so far.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:12
verses.text: That concupiscence, however, which we have to be ashamed of, and the shame of which has given to our secret members their shameful designation, pudenda, had no existence in the body during its life in paradise before the entrance of sin; but it began to exist "in the body of this death" after sin, the rebellion of the members retaliating man's own disobedience.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 26:13
verses.text: Without this concupiscence it was quite possible to effect the function of the wedded pair in the procreation of children: just as many a laborious work is accomplished by the compliant operation of our other limbs, without any lascivious heat; for they are simply moved by the direction of the will, not excited by the ardour of concupiscence.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 27.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:2
verses.text: —The Pelagians Argue that God Sometimes Closes the Womb in Anger, and Opens It When Appeased.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:3
verses.text: Carefully consider the rest of his remarks: "This likewise," says he, "is confirmed by the apostle's authority.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:4
verses.text: For when the blessed Paul spoke of the resurrection of the dead, he said, "Thou fool, that which thou sowest is not quickened".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:5
verses.text: And afterwards, 'But God giveth it a body as it pleaseth Him, and to every seed its own body.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:6
verses.text: ' If, therefore, God," says he, "has assigned to human seed, as to every thing else, its own proper body, which no wise or pious man will deny, how will you prove that any person is born guilty? Do, I beg of you, reflect with what a noose this assertion of natural sin is choked.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:7
verses.text: But come," he says, "deal more gently with yourself, I pray you.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:8
verses.text: Believe me, God made even you: it must, however, be confessed, that a serious error has infected you.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:9
verses.text: For what profaner opinion can be broached than that either God did not make man, or else that He made him for the devil; or, at any rate, that the devil framed God's image, that is, man,—which clearly is a statement not more absurd than impious? Is then," says he, "God so poor in resources, so lacking in all sense of propriety, as not to have had aught which He could confer on holy men as their reward, except what the devil, after making them his dupes, might infuse into them for their vitiation? Would you like to know, however, that even in the case of those who are no saints, God can be proved to have bestowed this power of procreation of children? When Abraham, struck with fear among a foreign nation, said that Sarah, his wife, was his sister, it is said that Abimelech, the king of the country, abducted her for a night's enjoyment of her.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:10
verses.text: But God, who had the holy woman's honour in His keeping, appeared to Abimelech in his sleep, and restrained the royal audacity; threatening him with death if he went to the length of violating the wife.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:11
verses.text: Then Abimelech said: 'Wilt thou, O Lord, slay an innocent and righteous nation? Did they not tell me that they were brother and sister? Therefore Abimelech arose early in the morning, and took a thousand pieces of silver, and sheep, and oxen, and men-servants, and women-servants, and gave them to Abraham, and sent away his wife untouched.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:12
verses.text: But Abraham prayed unto God for Abimelech; and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maid-servants.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:13
verses.text: '" Now why he narrated all this at so great a length, you may find in these few words which he added: "God," he says, "at the prayer of Abraham, restored their potency of generation, which had been taken away from the wombs of even the meanest servants; because God had closed up every womb in the house of Abimelech.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:14
verses.text: Consider now," says he, "whether that ought to be called a natural evil which sometimes God when angry takes away, and when appeased restores.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 27:15
verses.text: He," says he, "makes the children both of the pious and of the ungodly, inasmuch as the circumstance of their being parents appertains to that nature which rejoices in God as its Author, whilst the fact of their impiety belongs to the depravity of their desires, and this comes to every person whatever as the consequence of free will".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:1
verses.text: Chapter 28 (XIV.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:2
verses.text: )—Augustin's Answer to This Argument.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:3
verses.text: Its Dealing with Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:4
verses.text: Now to this lengthy statement of his we have to say in answer, that, in the passages which he has quoted from the sacred writings, there is nothing said about that shameful lust, which we say did not exist in the body of our first parents in their blessedness, when they were naked and were not ashamed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:5
verses.text: The first passage from the apostle was spoken of the seeds of corn, which first die in order to be quickened.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:6
verses.text: For some reason or other, he was unwilling to complete the verse for his quotation.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:7
verses.text: All he adduces from it is: "Thou fool, that which thou sowest is not quickened;" but the apostle adds, "except it die".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:8
verses.text: This writer, however, so far as I can judge, wished this passage, which treats only of corn seeds, to be understood of human seed, by such as read it without either understanding the Holy Scriptures or recollecting them.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:9
verses.text: Indeed, he not merely curtailed this particular sentence, by omitting the clause, "except it die," but he omitted the following words, in which the apostle explained of what seeds he was speaking; for the apostle adds: "And that which thou sowest, thou sowest not that body which shall be, but the bare grain, it may chance of wheat, or of some other grain".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:10
verses.text: This he omitted, and closed up his context with what the apostle then writes: "But God giveth it a body as it hath pleased Him, and to every seed its own body;" just as if the apostle spoke of man in cohabitation when he said, "Thou fool, that which thou sowest is not quickened," with a view to our understanding of human seed, that it is quickened by God, not by man in cohabitation begetting children.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:11
verses.text: For he had previously said: "Sexual pleasure does not complete the entire process of man's making, but rather presents to God, out of the treasures of nature, material with which He vouchsafes to make the human being".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:12
verses.text: He then added the quotation, as if the apostle affirmed as follows: Thou fool, that which thou sowest is not quickened,—quickened, that is, by thyself; but God forms the human being out of thy seed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:13
verses.text: As if the apostle had not said the intermediate words, which this writer chose to pass over; and as if the apostle's aim was to speak of human seed thus: "Thou fool, that which thou sowest is not quickened; but God giveth to the seed a body such as pleaseth Him, and to every seed its own body".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 28:14
verses.text: Indeed, after the apostle's words, he introduces remarks of his own to this effect: "If, therefore, God has assigned to human seed, as to everything else, its own proper body, which no wise or pious man will deny;" quite as if the apostle in the passage in question spoke of human seed.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:1
verses.text: Chapter 29.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:2
verses.text: —The Same Continued.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:3
verses.text: Augustin Also Asserts that God Forms Man at Birth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:4
verses.text: Though I have given special attention to the point, I have failed to discover what assistance he could obtain from this deceitful use of Scripture, except that he wanted to produce the apostle as a witness, and by him to prove, what we also assert, that God forms man of human seed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:5
verses.text: And inasmuch as no passage directly occurred to him, he deceitfully manipulated this particular one; fearing no doubt that, if the apostle should chance to seem to have spoken of corn seeds, and not of human, in this passage, we should have suggested to us at once by such procedure of his, how to refute him: not indeed as the pure-minded advocate of a chastened will, but as the impudent proclaimer of a profligate voluptuousness.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:6
verses.text: But from the very seeds, forsooth, which the farmers sow in their fields he can be refuted.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:7
verses.text: For why can we not suppose that God could have granted to man in his happy state in paradise, the same course with regard to his own seed which we see granted to the seeds of corn, in such wise that the former might be sown without any shameful lust, the members of generation simply obeying the inclination of the will; just as the latter is sown without any shameful lust, the hands of the husbandman merely moving in obedience to his will? There being, indeed, this difference, that the desire of begetting children in the parent is a nobler one than that which characterizes the farmer, of filling his barns.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 29:8
verses.text: Then, again, why might not the almighty Creator, with His incontaminable ubiquity, and his power of creating from human seed just what it pleased Him, have operated in women, with respect to what He even now makes, in the self-same manner as He operates in the ground with corn seeds according to His will, making blessed mothers conceive without lustful passion, and bring forth children without parturient pains, inasmuch as there was not (in that state of happiness, and in the body which was not as yet the body of this death, but rather of that life) in woman when receiving seed anything to produce shame, as there was nothing when giving birth to offspring to cause pain? Whoever refuses to believe this, or is unwilling to have it supposed that, while men previous to any sin lived in that happy state of paradise, such a condition as that which we have sketched could not have been permitted in God's will and kindness, must be regarded as the lover of shameful pleasure, rather than the encomiast of desirable fecundity.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 30 (XV.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30:2
verses.text: )—The Case of Abimelech and His House Examined.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30:3
verses.text: Then, again, as to the passage which he has adduced from the inspired history concerning Abimelech, and God's choosing to close up every womb in his household that the women should not bear children, and afterwards opening them that they might become fruitful, what is all this to the point? What has it to do with that shameful concupiscence which is now the question in dispute? Did God, then, deprive those women of this feeling, and give it to them again just when He liked? The punishment however, was that they were unable to bear children, and the blessing that they were able to bear them, after the manner of this corruptible flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30:4
verses.text: For God would not confer such a blessing upon this body of death, as only that body of life in paradise could have had before sin entered; that is, the process of conceiving without the prurience of lust, and of bearing children without excruciating pain.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30:5
verses.text: But why should we not suppose, since, indeed, Scripture says that every womb was closed, that this took place with something of pain, so that the women were unable to bear cohabitation, and that God inflicted this pain in His wrath, and removed it in His mercy? For if lust was to be taken away as an impediment to begetting offspring, it ought to have been taken away from the men, not from the women.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30:6
verses.text: For a woman might perform her share in cohabitation by her will, even if the lust ceased by which she is stimulated, provided it were not absent from the man for exciting him; unless, perhaps (as Scripture informs us that even Abimelech himself was healed), he would tell us that virile concupiscence was restored to him.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 30:7
verses.text: If, however, it were true that he had lost this, what necessity was there that he should be warned by God to hold no connection with Abraham's wife? The truth is, Abimelech is said to have been healed, because his household was cured of the affliction which smote it.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:1
verses.text: Chapter 31 (XVI.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:2
verses.text: )—Why God Proceeds to Create Human Beings, Who He Knows Will Be Born in Sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:3
verses.text: Let us now look at those three clauses of his, than which three, he says, nothing more profane could possibly be uttered: "Either God did not make man, or else He made him for the devil; or, at any rate, the devil framed God's image, that is, man".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:4
verses.text: Now, the first and the last of these sentences, even he himself must allow, if he be not reckless and perverse, were never uttered by us.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:5
verses.text: The dispute is confined to that which he puts second between the other two.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:6
verses.text: In respect of this, he is so far mistaken as to suppose that we had said that God made man for the devil; as if, in the case of human beings whom God creates of human parents, His care and purpose and provision were, that by means of His workmanship the devil should have as slaves those whom he is unable to make for himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:7
verses.text: God forbid that any sort of pious belief, however childish, should ever entertain such a sentiment as this! Of His own goodness God has made man—the first without sin, all others under sin—for the purposes of His own profound thoughts.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:8
verses.text: For just as He knew full well what to do with reference to the malice of the devil himself, and what He does is just and good, however unjust and evil he is, about whom He takes His measures; and just as He was not unwilling to create him because He foresaw that he would be evil; so in regard to the entire human race, though not a man of it is born without the taint of sin, He who is supremely good Himself is always working out good, making some men, as it were, "vessels of mercy," whom grace distinguishes from those who are "vessels of wrath;" whilst He makes others, as it were, "vessels of wrath," that He may make known the riches of His glory towards the vessels of mercy.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:9
verses.text: Let, then, this objector go and contest the point against the apostle, whose words I use; nay, against the very Potter, whom the apostle forbids us answering again, in the well-known words: "Who art thou, O man, that repliest against God! Shall the thing formed say to him that formed it, Why hast thou made me thus? Hath not the potter power over the clay, of the same lump to make one vessel unto honour, and another unto dishonour?"  Well now, will this man contend that the vessels of wrath are not under the dominion of the devil? or else, because they are under this dominion, are they made by another creator than He who makes the vessels of mercy? Or does He make them of other material, and not out of the self-same lump? Here, then, he may object, and say: "Therefore God makes these vessels for the devil".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 31:10
verses.text: As if God knew not how to make such a use of even these for the furtherance of His own good and righteous works, as He makes of the very devil himself.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 32

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 32:1
verses.text: Chapter 32 (XVII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 32:2
verses.text: )—God Not the Author of the Evil in Those Whom He Creates.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 32:3
verses.text: Then, does God feed the children of perdition, the goats on His left hand, for the devil and nourish and clothe them for the devil "because He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sendeth rain upon the just and the unjust"? He creates, then, the evil just in the same way as He feeds and nourishes the evil; because what He bestows on them by creating them appertains to the goodness of nature; and the growth which He gives them by food and nourishment, He bestows on them, of course, as a kindly help, not to their evil character, but to that same good nature which He in His goodness created.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 32:4
verses.text: For in as far as they are human beings—this is a good of that nature whose author and maker is God; but in as far as they are born with sin and so destined to perdition unless they are born again, they belong to the seed which was cursed from the beginning, by the fault of the primitive disobedience.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 32:5
verses.text: This fault, however, is turned to good account by the Maker of even the vessels of wrath, that He may make known the riches of His glory on the vessels of mercy: and that no one may attribute to any merits of his own, pertaining as he does to the self-same mass, his deliverance through grace; but "he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:1
verses.text: Chapter 33 (XVIII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:2
verses.text: )—Though God Makes Us, We Perish Unless He Re-makes Us in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:3
verses.text: From this most true and firmly-established principle of the apostolic and catholic faith the writer before us departs in company with the Pelagians.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:4
verses.text: He will not have it that men are born under the dominion of the devil, lest infants be carried to Christ to be delivered from the power of darkness, and to be translated into His kingdom.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:5
verses.text: Thus he becomes the accuser of the Church which is spread over the world; into this Church everywhere infants, when to be baptized, are first exorcised, for no other reason than that the prince of this world may be cast out of them.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:6
verses.text: For by him must they be necessarily possessed, as vessels of wrath, since they are born of Adam, unless they be born again in Christ, and transferred through grace as vessels of mercy into His kingdom.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:7
verses.text: In his attack, however, upon this most firmly-established truth, he would avoid the appearance of an assault upon the entire Church of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:8
verses.text: Accordingly, he limits his appeal to me alone, and in the tone of reproof and admonition he says: "But God made even you, though it must be confessed that a serious error has infected you".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:9
verses.text: Well now, I thankfully acknowledge that God did make even me; and still I must have perished with the vessels of wrath, if He had only made me of Adam, and had not re-made me in Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 33:10
verses.text: Possessed, however, as this man is with the heresy of Pelagius, he does not believe this: if, indeed, he persists in so great an error to the very end, then not he, but catholics, will be able to see the character and extent of the error which has not simply infected, but absolutely destroyed him.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:1
verses.text: Chapter 34 (XIX.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:2
verses.text: )—The Pelagians Argue that Cohabitation Rightly Used is a Good, and What is Born from It is Good.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:3
verses.text: I request your attention now to the following words.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:4
verses.text: He says, "That children, however, who are conceived in wedlock are by nature good, we may learn from the apostle's words, when he speaks of men who, leaving the natural use of the woman, burned in their lust, men with men working together that which is disgraceful.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:5
verses.text: Here," says he, "the apostle shows the use of the woman to be both natural and, in its way, laudable; the abuse consisting in the exercise of one's own will in opposition to the decent use of the institution.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:6
verses.text: Deservedly then," says he, "in those who make a right use thereof, concupiscence is commended in its kind and mode; whilst the excess of it, in which abandoned persons indulge, is punished.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:7
verses.text: Indeed, at the very time when God punished the abuse in Sodom with His judgment of fire, He invigorated the generative powers of Abraham and Sarah, which had become impotent through old age.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:8
verses.text: If, therefore," he goes on to say, "you think that fault must be found with the strength of the generative organs, because the Sodomites were steeped in sin thereby, you will have also to censure such created things as bread and wine, since Holy Scripture informs us that they sinned also in the abuse of these gifts.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:9
verses.text: For the Lord, by the mouth of His prophet Ezekiel, says: 'These, moreover, were the sins of thy sister Sodom; in their pride, she and her children overflowed in fulness of bread and abundance of wine; and they helped not the hand of the poor and needy.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:10
verses.text: ' Choose, therefore," says he, "which alternative you would rather have: either impute to the work of God the sexual connection of human bodies, or account such created things as bread and wine to be equally evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:11
verses.text: But if you should prefer this latter conclusion, you prove yourself to be a Manichean.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:12
verses.text: The truth, however, is this: he who observes moderation in natural concupiscence uses a good thing well; but he who does not observe moderation, abuses a good thing.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:13
verses.text: What means your statement, then," he asks, "when you say that 'the good of marriage is no more impeachable on account of the original sin which is derived herefrom, than the evil of adultery and fornication can be excused because of the natural good which is born of them'? In these words," says he, "you conceded what you had denied, and what you had conceded you nullified; and you aim at nothing so much as to be unintelligible.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:14
verses.text: Show me any bodily marriage without sexual connection.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:15
verses.text: Else impose some one name on this operation, and designate the conjugal union as either a good or an evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:16
verses.text: You answer, no doubt, that you have already defined marriages to be good.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 34:17
verses.text: Well then, if marriage is good,—if the human being is the good fruit of marriage; if this fruit, being God's work, cannot be evil, born as it is by good agency out of good,—where is the original evil which has been set aside by so many prior admissions?".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:1
verses.text: Chapter 35 (XX.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:2
verses.text: )—He Answers the Arguments of Julianus.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:3
verses.text: What is the Natural Use of the Woman? What is the Unnatural Use?  My answer to this challenge is, that not only the children of wedlock, but also those of adultery, are a good work in so far as they are the work of God, by whom they are created: but as concerns original sin, they are all born under condemnation of the first Adam; not only those who are born in adultery, but likewise such as are born in wedlock, unless they be regenerated in the second Adam, which is Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:4
verses.text: As to what the apostle says of the wicked, that "leaving the natural use of the woman, the men burned in their lust one toward another: men with men working that which is unseemly;" he did not speak of the conjugal use, but the "natural use," wishing us to understand how it comes to pass that by means of the members created for the purpose the two sexes can combine for generation.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:5
verses.text: Thus it follows, that even when a man unites with a harlot to use these members, the use is a natural one.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:6
verses.text: It is not, however, commendable, but rather culpable.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:7
verses.text: But as regards any part of the body which is not meant for generative purposes, should a man use even his own wife in it, it is against nature and flagitious.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:8
verses.text: Indeed, the same apostle had previously said concerning women: "Even their women did change the natural use into that which is against nature;" and then concerning men he added, that they worked that which is unseemly by leaving the natural use of the woman.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 35:9
verses.text: Therefore, by the phrase in question, "the natural use," it is not meant to praise conjugal connection; but thereby are denoted those flagitious deeds which are more unclean and criminal than even men's use of women, which, even if unlawful, is nevertheless natural.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:1
verses.text: Chapter 36 (XXI.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:2
verses.text: )—God Made Nature Good: the Saviour Restores It When Corrupted.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:3
verses.text: Now we do not reprehend bread and wine because some men are luxurious and drunkards, any more than we disapprove of gold because of the greedy and avaricious.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:4
verses.text: Wherefore on the same principle we do not censure the honourable connection between husband and wife, because of the shame-causing lust of bodies.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:5
verses.text: For the former would have been quite possible before any antecedent commission of sin, and by it the united pair would not have been made to blush; whereas the latter arose after the perpetration of sin, and they were obliged to hide it, from very shame.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:6
verses.text: Accordingly, in all united pairs ever since, however well and lawfully they have used this evil, there has been a permanent necessity of avoiding the sight of man in any work of this kind, and thus acknowledging what caused inevitable shame, though a good thing would certainly cause no man to be ashamed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:7
verses.text: In this way we have two distinct facts insensibly introduced to our notice: the good of that laudable union of the sexes for the purpose of generating children; and the evil of that shameful lust, in consequence of which the offspring must be regenerated in order to escape condemnation.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:8
verses.text: The man, therefore, who, though with the lust which causes shame, joins in lawful cohabitation, turns an evil to good account; whereas he who joins in an unlawful cohabitation uses an evil badly; for that is more correctly called evil than good, at which both bad and good alike blush.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:9
verses.text: We do better to believe him who has said, "I know that in me, that is, in my flesh, dwelleth no good thing," rather than him who calls that good, by which he is so conformed that he admits it to be evil; but if he feels no shame, he adds the worse evil of impudence.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:10
verses.text: Rightly then did we declare that "the good of marriage is no more impeachable because of the original sin which is derived therefrom, than the evil of adultery and fornication can be excused, because of the natural good which is born of them:" since the human nature which is born, whether of wedlock or of adultery, is the work of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:11
verses.text: Now if this nature were an evil, it ought not to have been born; if it had not evil, it would not have to be regenerated: and (that I may combine the two cases in one and the same predicate) if human nature were an evil thing, it would not have to be saved; if it had not in it any evil, it would not have to be saved.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:12
verses.text: He, therefore, who contends that nature is not good, says that the Maker of the creature is not good; whilst he who will have it, that nature has no evil in it, deprives it in its corrupted condition of a merciful Saviour.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 36:13
verses.text: From this, then, it follows, that in the birth of human beings neither fornication is to be excused on account of the good which is formed out of it by the good Creator, nor is marriage to be impeached by reason of the evil which has to be healed in it by the merciful Saviour.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37:1
verses.text: Chapter 37 (XXII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37:2
verses.text: )—If There is No Marriage Without Cohabitation, So There is No Cohabitation Without Shame.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37:3
verses.text: "Show me," he says, "any bodily marriage without sexual connection".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37:4
verses.text: I do not show him any bodily marriage without sexual connection; but then, neither does he show me any case of sexual connection which is without shame.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37:5
verses.text: In paradise, however, if sin had not preceded, there would not have been, indeed, generation without union of the sexes, but this union would certainly have been without shame; for in the sexual union there would have been a quiet acquiescence of the members, not a lust of the flesh productive of shame.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37:6
verses.text: Matrimony, therefore, is a good, in which the human being is born after orderly conception; the fruit, too, of matrimony is good, as being the very human being which is thus born; sin, however, is an evil with which every man is born.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 37:7
verses.text: Now it was God who made and still makes man; but "by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for in him all sinned".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:1
verses.text: Chapter 38 (XXIII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:2
verses.text: )—Jovinian Used Formerly to Call Catholics Manicheans; The Arians Also Used to Call Catholics Sabellians.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:3
verses.text: "By your new mode of controversy," says he, "you both profess to be a catholic and patronize Manichaeus, inasmuch as you designate matrimony both as a great good and a great evil".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:4
verses.text: Now he is utterly ignorant of what he says, or pretends to be ignorant.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:5
verses.text: Or else he does not understand what we say, or does not wish it to be understood.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:6
verses.text: But if he does not understand, he is impeded by the pre-occupation of error; or if he does not wish our meaning to be understood, then obstinacy is the fault with which he defends his error.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:7
verses.text: Jovinian, too, who endeavoured a few years ago to found a new heresy, used to declare that the catholics patronized the Manicheans, because in opposition to him they preferred holy virginity to marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:8
verses.text: But this man is sure to reply, that he does not agree with Jovinian in his indifference about marriage and virginity.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:9
verses.text: I do not myself say that this is their opinion; still these new heretics must allow, by the fact of Jovinian's playing off the Manicheans upon the catholics, that the expedient is not a novel one.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:10
verses.text: We then declare that marriage is a good, not an evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:11
verses.text: But just as the Arians charge us with being Sabellians, although we do not say that the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Ghost are one and the same, as the Sabellians hold; but affirm that the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Ghost have one and the same nature, as the catholics believe: so do the Pelagians cast the Manicheans in our teeth, although we do not declare marriage to be an evil, as the Manicheans pretend, but affirm that evil accrued to the first man and woman, that is to say, to the first married pair, and from them passed on to all men, as the catholics hold.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 38:12
verses.text: As, however, the Arians, while avoiding the Sabellians, fall into worse company, because they have had the audacity to divide not the Persons of the Trinity, but the natures; so the Pelagians, in their efforts to escape from the pestilent error of the Manicheans, by taking the opposite extreme, are convicted of entertaining worse sentiments than the Manicheans themselves touching the fruit of matrimony, inasmuch as they believe that infants stand in no need of Christ as their Physician.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:1
verses.text: Chapter 39 (XXIV.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:2
verses.text: )—Man Born of Whatever Parentage is Sinful and Capable of Redemption.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:3
verses.text: He then says: "You conclude that a human being, if born of fornication, is not guilty; and if born in wedlock, is not innocent.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:4
verses.text: Your assertion, therefore, amounts to this, that natural good may possibly subsist from adulterous connections, while original sin is actually derived from marriage".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:5
verses.text: Well now, he here attempts, but in vain before an intelligent reader, to give a wrong turn to words which are correct enough.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:6
verses.text: Far be it from us to say, that a human being, if born in fornication, is not guilty.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:7
verses.text: But we do affirm, that a human being, whether he be born in wedlock or in fornication, is in some respect good, because of the Author of nature, God; we add, however, that he derives some evil by reason of original sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 39:8
verses.text: Our statement, therefore, "that natural good can subsist even from adulterous parentage, but that original sin is derived even from marriage," does not amount to what he endeavours to make of it, that one born in adultery is not guilty, nor innocent when born in wedlock; but that one who is generated in either condition is guilty, because of original sin; and that the offspring of either state may be freed by regeneration, because of the good of nature.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:1
verses.text: Chapter 40 (XXV.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:2
verses.text: )—Augustin Declines the Dilemma Offered Him.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:3
verses.text: "One of these propositions," says he, "is true, the other false".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:4
verses.text: My reply is as brief as the allegation: Both are really true, neither is false.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:5
verses.text: "It is true," he goes on to say, "that the sin of adultery cannot be excused by reason of the man who is born of it; inasmuch as the sin which adulterers commit, pertains to corruption of the will; but the offspring which they produce tends to the praise of fecundity.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:6
verses.text: If one were to sow wheat which had been stolen, the crop which springs up is none the worse.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:7
verses.text: Of course," says he, "I blame the thief, but I praise the corn.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 40:8
verses.text: So I pronounce him innocent who is born of the generous fruitfulness of the seed; even as the apostle puts it: 'God giveth it a body, as it pleases Him; and to every seed its own body;' but, at the same time, I condemn the flagitious man who has committed his adulterous sin in his perverse use of the divine appointment".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:1
verses.text: Chapter 41 (XXVI.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:2
verses.text: )—The Pelagians Argue that Original Sin Cannot Come Through Marriage If Marriage is Good.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:3
verses.text: After this he proceeds with the following words: "Certainly if evil is contracted from marriage, it may be blamed, nay, cannot be excused; and you place under the devil's power its work and fruit, because everything which is the cause of evil is itself without good.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:4
verses.text: The human being, however, who is born of wedlock owes his origin not to the reproaches of wedlock, but to its seminal elements: the cause of these, however, lies in the condition of bodies; and whosoever makes a bad use of these bodies, deals a blow at the good desert thereof, not at their nature.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:5
verses.text: It is therefore clear," argues he, "that the good is not the cause of the evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:6
verses.text: If, therefore," he continues, "original evil is derived even from marriage, the cause of the evil is the compact of marriage; and that must needs be evil by which and from which the evil fruit has made its appearance; even as the Lord says in the Gospel: 'A tree is known by its fruits.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:7
verses.text: '  How then," he asks, "do you think yourself worthy of attention, when you say that marriage is good, and yet declare that nothing but evil proceeds from it? It is evident, then, that marriages are guilty, since original sin is deduced from them; and they are indefensible, too, unless their fruit be proved innocent.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 41:8
verses.text: But they are defended, and pronounced good; therefore their fruit is proved to be innocent".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:1
verses.text: Chapter 42.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:2
verses.text: —The Pelagians Try to Get Rid of Original Sin by Their Praise of God's Works; Marriage, in Its Nature and by Its Institution, is Not the Cause of Sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:3
verses.text: I have an answer ready for all this; but before I give it, I wish the reader carefully to notice, that the result of the opinions of these persons is, that no Saviour is necessary for infants, whom they deem to be entirely without any sins to be saved from.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:4
verses.text: This vast perversion of the truth, so hostile to God's great grace, which is given through our Lord Jesus Christ, who "came to seek and to save what was lost," tries to insinuate its way into the hearts of the unintelligent by eulogizing the works of God; that is, by its eulogy of human nature, of human seed, of marriage, of sexual intercourse, of the fruits of matrimony—which are all of them good things.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:5
verses.text: I will not say that he adds the praise of lust; because he too is ashamed even to name it, so that it is something else, and not it, which he seems to praise.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:6
verses.text: By this method of his, not distinguishing between the evils which have accrued to nature and the goodness of nature's very self, he does not, indeed, show it to be sound (because that is untrue), but he does not permit its diseased condition to be healed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:7
verses.text: And, therefore, that first proposition of ours, to the effect that the good thing, even the human being, which is born of adultery, does not excuse the sin of adulterous connection, he allows to be true; and this point, which occasions no question to arise between us, he even defends and strengthens (as he well may) by his similitude of the thief who sows the seed which he stole, and out of which there arises a really good harvest.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:8
verses.text: Our other proposition, however, that "the good of marriage cannot be blamed for the original sin which is derived from it," he will not admit to be true; if, indeed, he assented to it, he would not be a Pelagian heretic, but a catholic Christian.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:9
verses.text: "Certainly," says he, "if evil arises from marriage, it may be blamed, nay, cannot be excused; and you place its work and fruit under the devil's power, because everything which is the cause of evil is itself without good".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:10
verses.text: And in addition to this, he contrived other arguments to show that good could not possibly be the cause of evil; and from this he drew the inference, that marriage, which is a good, is not the cause of evil; and that consequently from it no man could be born in a sinful state, and having need of a Saviour: just as if we said that marriage is the cause of sin, though it is true that the human being which is born in wedlock is not born without sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:11
verses.text: Marriage was instituted not for the purpose of sinning, but of producing children.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:12
verses.text: Accordingly the Lord's blessing on the married state ran thus: "Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:13
verses.text: The sin, however, which is derived to children from marriage does not belong to marriage, but to the evil which accrues to the human agents, from whose union marriage comes into being.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:14
verses.text: The truth is, both the evil of shameful lust can exist without marriage, and marriage might have been without it.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:15
verses.text: It appertains, however, to the condition of the body (not of that life, but) of this death, that marriage cannot exist without it though it may exist without marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:16
verses.text: Of course that lust of the flesh which causes shame has existence out of the married state, whenever it urges men to the commission of adultery, chambering and uncleanness, so utterly hostile to the purity of marriage; or again, when it does not commit any of these things, because the human agent gives no permission or assent to their commission, but still rises and is set in motion and creates disturbance, and (especially in dreams) effects the likeness of its own veritable work, and reaches the end of its own emotion.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:17
verses.text: Well, now, this is an evil which is not even in the married state actually an evil of marriage; but it has this apparatus all ready in the body of this death, even against its own will, which is indispensable no doubt for the accomplishment of that which it does will.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 42:18
verses.text: The evil in question, therefore, does not accrue to marriage from its own institution, which was blessed; but entirely from the circumstance that sin entered into the world by one man, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for in him all sinned.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:1
verses.text: Chapter 43.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:2
verses.text: —The Good Tree in the Gospel that Cannot Bring Forth Evil Fruit, Does Not Mean Marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:3
verses.text: What, then, does he mean by saying, "A tree is known by its fruits," on the ground of our reading that the Lord spake thus in the Gospel? Was, then, the Lord speaking of this question in these words, and not rather of men's two wills, the good and the evil, calling one of these the good tree, and the other the corrupt tree, inasmuch as good works spring out of a good will, and evil ones out of an evil will—the converse being impossible, good works out of an evil will, and evil ones out of a good will? If, however, we were to suppose marriage to be the good tree, according to the Gospel simile which he has mentioned, then, of course, we must on the other hand assume fornication to be the corrupt tree.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:4
verses.text: Wherefore, if a human being is said to be the fruit of marriage, in the sense of the good fruit of a good tree, then undoubtedly a human being could never have been born in fornication.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:5
verses.text: "For a corrupt tree bringeth not forth good fruit".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:6
verses.text: Once more, if he were to say that not adultery must be supposed to occupy the place of the tree, but rather human nature, of which man is born, then in this way not even marriage can stand for the tree, but only the human nature of which man is born.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:7
verses.text: His simile, therefore, taken from the Gospel avails him nothing in elucidating this question, because marriage is not the cause of the sin which is transmitted in the natural birth, and atoned for in the new birth; but the voluntary transgression of the first man is the cause of original sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:8
verses.text: "You repeat," says he, "your allegation, 'Just as sin, from whatever source it is derived to infants, is the work of the devil, so man, howsoever he be born, is the work of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 43:9
verses.text: '" Yes, I said this, and most truly too; and if this man were not a Pelagian, but a catholic, he too would have nothing else to avow in the catholic faith.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:1
verses.text: Chapter 44 (XXVII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:2
verses.text: )—The Pelagians Argue that If Sin Comes by Birth, All Married People Deserve Condemnation.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:3
verses.text: What, then, is his object when he inquires of us, "By what means sin may be found in an infant, through the will, or through marriage, or through its parents"? He speaks, indeed, in such a way as if he had an answer to all these questions, and as if by clearing all of sin together he would have nothing remain in the infant whence sin could be found.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:4
verses.text: I beg your attention to his very words: "Through what," says he, "is sin found in an infant? Through the will? But there has never been one in him? Through marriage? But this appertains to the parents' work, of whom you had previously declared that in this action they had not sinned; though it appears from your subsequent words that you did not make this concession truly.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:5
verses.text: Marriage, therefore," he says, "must be condemned, since it furnished the cause of the evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:6
verses.text: Yet marriage only indicates the work of personal agents.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:7
verses.text: The parents, therefore, who by their coming together afforded occasion for the sin, are properly deserving of the condemnation.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:8
verses.text: It does not then admit of doubt," says he, "any longer, if we are to follow your opinion, that married persons are handed over to eternal punishment, it being by their means brought about that the devil has come to exercise dominion over men.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:9
verses.text: And what becomes of what you just before had said, that man was the work of God? Because if through their birth it happens that evil is in men, and through the evil that the devil has power over men, so in fact you declare the devil to be the author of men, from whom comes their origin at birth.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 44:10
verses.text: If, however, you believe that man is made by God, and that husband and wife are innocent, see how impossible is your standpoint, that original sin is derived from them".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45:1
verses.text: Chapter 45.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45:2
verses.text: —Answer to This Argument: The Apostle Says We All Sinned in One.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45:3
verses.text: Now, there is an answer for him to all these questions given by the apostle, who censures neither the infant's will, which is not yet matured in him for sinning, nor marriage, which, as such, has not only its institution, but its blessing also, from God; nor parents, so far as they are parents, who are united together properly and lawfully for the procreation of children; but he says, "By one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men for in him all have sinned".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45:4
verses.text: Now, if these persons would only receive this statement with catholic hearts and ears, they would not have rebellious feelings against the grace and faith of Christ, nor would they vainly endeavour to convert to their own particular and heretical sense these very clear and manifest words of the apostle, when they assert that the purport of the passage is to this effect: that Adam was the first to sin, and that any one who wished afterwards to commit sin found an example for sinning in him; so that sin, you must know, did not pass from this one upon all men by birth, but by the imitation of this one.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45:5
verses.text: Whereas it is certain that if the apostle meant this imitation to be here understood, he would have said that sin had entered into the world and passed upon all men, not by one man, but rather by the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45:6
verses.text: For of the devil it is written: "They that are on his side do imitate him".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 45:7
verses.text: He used the phrase "by one man," from whom the generation of men, of course, had its beginning, in order to show us that original sin had passed upon all men by generation.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:1
verses.text: Chapter 46.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:2
verses.text: —The Reign of Death, What It Is; The Figure of the Future Adam; How All Men are Justified Through Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:3
verses.text: But what else is meant even by the apostle's subsequent words? For after he had said the above, he added, "For until the law sin was in the world," as much as to say that not even the law was able to take away sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:4
verses.text: "But sin," adds he, "was not imputed when there was no law".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:5
verses.text: It existed then, but was not imputed, for it was not set forth so that it might be imputed.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:6
verses.text: It is on the same principle, indeed, that he says in another passage: "By the law is the knowledge of sin".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:7
verses.text: "Nevertheless," says he, "death reigned from Adam to Moses;" that is, as he had already expressed it, "until the law".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:8
verses.text: Not that there was no sin after Moses, but because even the law, which was given by Moses, was unable to deprive death of its power, which, of course, reigns only by sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:9
verses.text: Its reign, too, is such as to plunge mortal man even into that second death which is to endure for evermore.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:10
verses.text: "Death reigned," but over whom? "Even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of Him that was to come".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:11
verses.text: Of whom that was to come, if not Christ? And in what sort a figure, except in the way of contrariety? which he elsewhere briefly expresses: "As in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:12
verses.text: The one condition was in one, even as the other condition was in the other; this is the figure.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:13
verses.text: But this figure is not conformable in every respect; accordingly the apostle, following up the same idea, added, "But not as the offence, so also is the free gift.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:14
verses.text: For if through the offence of one many be dead; much more the grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man, Jesus Christ, hath abounded unto many".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:15
verses.text: But why "hath it much more abounded," except it be that all who are delivered through Christ suffer temporal death on Adam's account, but have everlasting life in store for the sake of Christ Himself? "And not as it was by one that sinned," says he, "so is the gift: for the judgment was from one to condemnation, but the free gift is from many offences unto justification".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:16
verses.text: "By one" what, but offence? since it is added, "the free gift is from many offences".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:17
verses.text: Let these objectors tell us how it can be "by one offence unto condemnation," unless it be that even the one original sin which has passed over unto all men is sufficient for condemnation? Whereas the free gift delivers from many offences to justification, because it not only cancels the one offence, which is derived from the primal sin, but all others also which are added in every individual man by the motion of his own will.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:18
verses.text: "For if by one man's offence death reigned by one, much more they which receive abundance of grace and righteousness shall reign in life by One, Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:19
verses.text: Therefore, by the offence of one upon all men to condemnation; so by the righteousness of one upon all men unto justification of life".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:20
verses.text: Let them after this persist in their vain imaginations, and maintain that one man did not hand on sin by propagation, but only set the example of committing it.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:21
verses.text: How is it, then, that by one's offence judgment comes on all men to condemnation, and not rather by each man's own numerous sins, unless it be that even if there were but that one sin, it is sufficient, without the addition of any more, to lead to condemnation,—as, indeed, it does lead all who die in infancy who are born of Adam, without being born again in Christ? Why, then, does he, when he refuses to hear the apostle, ask us for an answer to his question, "By what means may sin be discovered in an infant,—through the will, or through marriage, or through its parents?" Let him listen in silence, and hear by what means sin may be discovered in an infant.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:22
verses.text: "By the offence of one," says the apostle, "upon all men to condemnation".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:23
verses.text: He said, moreover, all to condemnation through Adam, and all to justification through Christ: not, of course, that Christ removes to life all those who die in Adam; but he said "all" and "all," because, as without Adam no one goes to death, so without Christ no man to life.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:24
verses.text: Just as we say of a teacher of letters, when he is alone in a town: This man teaches all their learning; not because all the inhabitants take lessons, but because no man who learns at all is taught by any but him.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:25
verses.text: Indeed, the apostle afterwards designates as many those whom he had previously described as all, meaning the self-same persons by the two different terms.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 46:26
verses.text: "For," says he, "as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous".

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:1
verses.text: Chapter 47.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:2
verses.text: —The Scriptures Repeatedly Teach Us that All Sin in One.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:3
verses.text: Still let him ply his question: "By what means may sin be discovered in an infant?" He may find an answer in the inspired pages: "By one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for in him all sinned".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:4
verses.text: "Through the offence of one many are dead".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:5
verses.text: "The judgment was from one to condemnation".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:6
verses.text: "By one man's offence death reigned by one".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:7
verses.text: "By the offence of one, Judgment came upon all men to condemnation".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:8
verses.text: "By one man's disobedience many were made sinners".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:9
verses.text: Behold, then, "by what means sins may be discovered in an infant".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:10
verses.text: Let him now believe in original sin; let him permit infants to come to Christ, that they may be saved.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:11
verses.text: (XXVIII.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:12
verses.text: ) What means this passage of his: "He sins not who is born; he sins not who begat him; He sins not who created him.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:13
verses.text: Amidst these intrenchments of innocence, therefore, what are the breaches through which you pretend that sin entered?" Why does he search for a hidden chink when he has an open door? "By one man," says the apostle; "through the offence of one," says the apostle; "By one man's disobedience," says the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 47:14
verses.text: What does he want more? What does he require plainer? What does he expect to be more impressively repeated?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:1
verses.text: Chapter 48.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:2
verses.text: —Original Sin Arose from Adam's Depraved Will.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:3
verses.text: Whence the Corrupt Will Sprang.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:4
verses.text: "If," says he, "sin comes from the will, it is an evil will that causes sin; if it comes from nature, then nature is evil".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:5
verses.text: I at once answer, Sin does come from the will.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:6
verses.text: Perhaps he wants to know, whether original sin also? I answer, most certainly original sin also.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:7
verses.text: Because it, too, was engendered from the will of the first man; so that it both existed in him, and passed on to all.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:8
verses.text: As for what he next proposes, "If it comes from nature, then nature is evil," I request him to answer, if he can, to this effect: As it is manifest that all evil works spring from a corrupt will, like the fruits of a corrupt tree; so let him say whence arose the corrupt will itself—the corrupt tree which yields the corrupt fruits.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:9
verses.text: If from an angel, what was the angel, but the good work of God? If from man, what was even he, but the good work of God? Nay, inasmuch as the corrupt will arose in the angel from an angel, and in man from man, what were both these, previous to the evil arising within them, but the good work of God, with a good and laudable nature? Behold, then, evil arises out of good; nor was there any other source, indeed, whence it could arise, but out of good.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:10
verses.text: I call that will bad which no evil has preceded; no evil works, of course, since they only proceed from an evil will, as from a corrupt tree.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:11
verses.text: Nevertheless, that the evil will arose out of good, could not be, because that good was made by the good God, but because it was created out of nothing—not out of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:12
verses.text: What, therefore, becomes of his argument, "If nature is the work of God, it will never do for the work of the devil to permeate the work of God"? Did not the work of the devil, I ask, arise in a work of God, when it first arose in that angel who became the devil? Well, then, if evil, which was absolutely nowhere previously, could arise in a work of God, why could not evil, which had by this time found an existence somewhere, pervade the work of God; especially when the apostle uses the very expression in the passage, "And so death passed upon all men"? Can it be that men are not the work of God? Sin, therefore, has passed upon all men—in other words, the devil's work has penetrated the work of God; or putting the same meaning in another shape, The work done by a work of God has pervaded God's work.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 48:13
verses.text: And this is the reason why God alone has an unchangeable and almighty goodness: even before any evil came into existence He made all things good; and out of all the evils which have arisen in the good things which He has made, He works through all for good.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:1
verses.text: Chapter 49 (XXIX.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:2
verses.text: )—In Infants Nature is of God, and the Corruption of Nature of the Devil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:3
verses.text: "In a single man rightly is the intention blamed and the origin praised; because there must be two things to admit of contraries: in an infant, however, there is but one thing, nature only; because will has no existence in his case.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:4
verses.text: Now this one thing," says he, "is ascribable either to God or to the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:5
verses.text: If nature," he goes on to observe, "is of God, there cannot be original evil in it.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:6
verses.text: If of the devil, there will be nothing on the ground of which man may be vindicated for the work of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:7
verses.text: So that he is completely a Manichean who maintains original sin".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:8
verses.text: Let him hear rather what is true in opposition to all this.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:9
verses.text: In a single man the will is to be blamed, and his nature to be praised; because there should be two things for the application of contraries.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:10
verses.text: Still, even in an infant, it is not the case that there is but one thing only, that is, the nature in which man was created by the good God; for he has also that corruption, which has passed upon all men by one, as the apostle wisely says, and not as the folly of Pelagius, or Coelestius, or any of their disciples would represent the matter.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:11
verses.text: Of these two things, then, which we have said exist in an infant, one is ascribed to God, the other to the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:12
verses.text: From the fact, however, that (owing to one of the two, even the corruption) both are subjected to the power of the devil, there really ensues no incongruity; because this happens not from the power of the devil himself, but of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 49:13
verses.text: In fact, corruption is subjected to corruption, nature to nature, because the two are even in the devil; so that whenever those who are beloved and elect are "delivered from the power of darkness" to which they are justly exposed, it is clear enough how great a gift is bestowed on the justified and good by the good God, who brings good even out of evil.

chapters.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:1
verses.text: Chapter 50.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:2
verses.text: —The Rise and Origin of Evil.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:3
verses.text: The Exorcism and Exsufflation of Infants, a Primitive Christian Rite.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:4
verses.text: As to the passage, which he seemed to himself to indite in a pious vein, as it were, "If nature is of God, there cannot be original sin in it," would not another person seem even to him to give a still more pious turn to it, thus: "If nature is of God, there cannot arise any sin in it?" And yet this is not true.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:5
verses.text: The Manicheans, indeed, meant to assert this, and they endeavoured to steep in all sorts of evil the very nature of God itself, and not His creature, made out of nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:6
verses.text: For evil arose in nothing else than what was good—not, however, the supreme and unchangeable good which is God's nature, but that which was made out of nothing by the wisdom of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:7
verses.text: This, then, is the reason why man is claimed for a divine work; for he would not be man unless he were made by the operation of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:8
verses.text: But evil would not exist in infants, if evil had not been committed by the wilfulness of the first man, and original sin derived from a nature thus corrupted.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:9
verses.text: It is not true, then, as he puts it, "He is completely a Manichean who maintains original sin;" but rather, he is completely a Pelagian who does not believe in original sin.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:10
verses.text: For it is not simply from the time when the pestilent opinions of Manichaeus began to grow that in the Church of God infants about to be baptized were for the first time exorcised with exsufflation,—which ceremonial was intended to show that they were not removed into the kingdom of Christ without first being delivered from the power of darkness; nor is it in the books of Manichaeus that we read how "the Son of man come to seek and to save that which was lost," or how "by one man sin entered into the world," with those other similar passages which we have quoted above; or how God "visits the sins of the fathers upon the children;" or how it is written in the Psalm, "I was shapen in iniquity, and in sin did my mother conceive me;" or again, how "man was made like unto vanity: his days pass away like a shadow;" or again, "behold, Thou hast made my days old, and my existence as nothing before Thee; nay, every man living is altogether vanity;" or how the apostle says, "every creature was made subject to vanity;" or how it is written in the book of Ecclesiastes, "vanity of vanities; all is vanity: what profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?" and in the book of Ecclesiasticus, "a heavy yoke is upon the sons of Adam from the day that they go out of their mother's womb to the day that they return to the mother of all things;" or how again the apostle writes, "in Adam all die;" or how holy Job says, when speaking about his own sins, "for man that is born of a woman is short-lived and full of wrath: as the flower of grass, so does he fall; and he departs like a shadow, nor shall he stay.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:11
verses.text: Hast Thou not taken account even of him, and caused him to enter into judgment in Thy sight? For who shall be pure from uncleanness? Not even one, even if his life should be but of one day upon the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:12
verses.text: Now when he speaks of uncleanness here, the mere perusal of the passage is enough to show that he meant sin to be understood.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:13
verses.text: It is plain from the words, of what he is speaking.

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:14
verses.text: The same phrase and sense occur in the prophet Zechariah, in the place where "the filthy garments" are removed from off the high priest, and it is said to him, "I have taken away thy sins".

verses.name: Augustine: On marriage and Concupiscense Book II 50:15
